title: Suitor moves to allay fears over its £4bn Cobham deal
text:
The predatory private equity firm hoping to buy Cobham is close to hammering out an agreement with the Government to push the takeover through.

Advent International, which agreed to scoop up Cobham for £4bn in September, is negotiating a list of commitments designed to allay fears that the deal will threaten British jobs and the defence industry.

Lady Cobham said the firm is 'being hawked off to the Americans'

Sources close to Advent said the firm was in ‘advanced discussions’ with Government ministers. Advent will promise to continue investing in Cobham’s UK research and development efforts, maintain employment levels, keep existing sector headquarters in the country and protect the Cobham brand.

Nadine Cobham, the daughter-in-law of Cobham’s founder Sir Alan Cobham, said Advent’s promises ‘make a mockery’ of the Government’s efforts to reinvigorate UK trade.

Lady Cobham added: ‘Our defence manufacturing capability is being hawked off to the Americans in the hopes it facilitates a post-Brexit trade deal – something the US has no intention of reciprocating.’
